question.title: Search In Infinite Sorted 0-1 Array
question.content:
You are given an infinite array consisting of only ones and zeroes, in sorted order. You have to find the index of the first occurrence of 1.

Example:
If the array is 0 0 0 0 1 1 1 1… then, the first occurrence of 1 will be at index 4 therefore the answer here is 4.
Note:
As the array size is infinite, the actual array won’t be given to you. Instead, you will be able to access the array elements by calling a method named ‘get’.

get(i) : returns the value present at index I.

Indexing is 0-based. 

Instead of representing an infinite array in the input, we give the index of the first occurrence of 1 in the input itself. However, this input will be completely hidden from the user.

It is guaranteed that the answer will fit in a 64-bit integer.
Input Format:
The only input line contains an integer X, the index of the first occurrence of 1. (Hidden to the user)
Output Format:
Print an integer denoting the index of the first occurrence of 1.

Note:

You do not need to print anything, the output has already been taken care of. Just implement the given function.
Constraints:
0 <= ARR[i] <= 1

Time limit: 1sec
Sample Input 1:
10
Sample Output 1:
10
Sample Input 2:
1
Sample Output 2:
1

rephrased.body: Given an infinite sorted array containing only 0s and 1s, find the index of the first occurrence of 1. You have access to the array through a `get(i)` function that returns the value at index `i`. Implement the `firstOne()` function to find this index efficiently.
constraints: It is guaranteed that the answer will fit in a 64-bit integer.

testcases.explanation: The first occurrence of 1 is at index 10.
The first occurrence of 1 is at index 1.
The first element itself is 1 at index 0.
The first occurrence of 1 is at index 100.
The first occurence of 1 is at index 5.

hints: Linear searching will take too long, in an infinite array. Can we use the fact that this array is sorted? How do we get around the fact that the size of this array is infinite?
